Description: Body sherd (mended from six fragments) of large Corinthian black-figured pottery alabastron; exterior: parts of two friezes preserved, separated by a band of staggered dots between pairs of lines; above: black-figure decoration of probably confronted cocks (parts of wing with added red, body, neck and leg of bird to right and perhaps chest of second to left); incised splinter and spoked rosettes as filling ornament, as well as two enigmatic rectangles with unusual incision below front of left bird; below, perhaps head and back of panther to right; incised splinter rosette as filling ornament. Most glaze lost and also any added red or white.
Curator's comments: This registration number has been wrongly given to another vase (a transitional alabastron) by Payne (1931, 286, no. 467), followed by Venit (1982, 50, no. A3) and Möller (2000, no. 8).
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 84, no. A101)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 219, no.29)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.144) (Phase 1)
